items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely between approximately 12:30pm and 2pm this afternoon, Thursday 9th October.  This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Thursday 9th October.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  today between 1pm and 3pm on Thursday 9th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.53mAODN at 2pm, on Thursday 9th October, which is 0.21m above tide tables, wind Force 3, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Thursday 9th October.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
High tide levels and large waves may lead to flooding this morning, Thursday 09/10/2025. Flooding of roads, low lying land, and exposed areas of the coast is possible. 

Flooding is possible between 04:30AM and 07:00AM. Areas most at risk include exposed areas of the coast particularly around Whitby, and The North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including Sandsend and the tidal River Esk. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths, and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We are currently in a period of high tides so this alert may be re-issued if necessary. This message will be updated by 08:00PM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  today between 1pm and 3pm on Thursday 9th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.53mAODN at 2pm, on Thursday 9th October, which is 0.21m above tide tables, wind Force 3, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today, Thursday 9th October.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.70mAOD at 16:45 on 09/10/2025.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 10 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Higher than normal spring tides are forecast this evening. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The forecast high-water is 9:45 PM today 09/10/25 with a level of 7.48 mAOD and a Force 3 North-Westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. 
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates at Pill. Please be careful along low-lying land near watercourses where conditions may be hazardous.
This message will be updated tomorrow 10/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced, however, standing water may remain, so take care near coastal paths and promenades.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
High tides are expected to reach the flood alert threshold overnight which may lead to flooding between 01:30 AM and 03:00 AM on 09/10/2025.  The impacted locations are:
 
Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 02:00 AM
 
Eastford Road, peaking around 02:15 AM
 
Arpley Bridge, peaking around 02:30 AM
 
Knutsford Road, peaking around 02:30 AM
 
It is possible that river levels will also affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 
 
The lunchtime tide tomorrow, 09/10/2025 will not reach flood alert, but the overnight tide on 10/10/2025 will pass the flood alert threshold.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High spring tides are expected until Friday 10 October. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

The lunchtime tide at 13:30 PM on Thursday 9 October is not forecast to reach flood alert levels. The following high tide at 01:45 AM on Friday 10 October is forecast to reach flood alert level at Sandside and Arnside. The lunchtime tide at 14:05 PM on Friday 10 October, and subsequent tides, are all below flood alert level. Tide levels may be high 2 hours either side of peak level timings.

Areas that may be affected are the Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Canal Foot, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
 
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as tidal floodwater is expected to impact these low lying areas. Do not attempt to drive through floodwater.
 
This message will be updated by 15:30 PM on Thursday 9 October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
We do not expect to see flooding from the midday high tide today on 09/10/2025. However flooding is possible tonight due to higher than normal tides, with the high tide peaking at 01:45am on 10/10/2025.
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 9:30 AM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High tide levels and large waves may lead to flooding this morning, Thursday 09/10/2025. Flooding of roads, low lying land, and exposed areas of the coast is possible. Flooding is possible between 06:00AM and 08:30AM. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths, and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We are currently in a period of high tides so this alert may be re-issued if necessary.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
Flooding is possible around the peak of the high tide on Thursday evening (09/10/2025) at 5:30 PM.

Flooding is also possible on the subsequent high tide at 5:45 AM on Friday morning (10/10/2025).

Areas most at risk include Newcastle Quayside.

Please note levels are not expected to be as high as they were on Thursday morning.  
 
Tidal conditions are expected to improve following the high tide on Friday morning after which no further flooding is expected.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid roads, footpaths and carparks at Newcastle Quayside, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today between 1:00pm and 3:00pm on Thursday 9th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.93mAODN at 2:00pm, on Thursday 9th October, which is 0.09m above tide tables, wind Force 3, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Thursday 9th October.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued due to a period of high tides. 
Tides will be at their highest around 21:30 this evening 09/10/25 and at 09:45 on Friday morning 10/10/25. Flooding of roads and low-lying land adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow is expected at the time of high tides, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tides. 
Predicted peaks this evening Thursday 09/10/25: Newport 6.9m to 7.3m around 21:30 and Avonmouth 7.3m to 7.6m around 21:45. 
Predicted peaks tomorrow morning Friday 09/10/25: Newport 6.6m to 6.9m around 09:45 and Avonmouth 7.0m to 7.2m around 10:00. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 11:00 on 10/10/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today between 1:30pm and 3:30pm on Thursday 9th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to spring tides.  Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.4 mAODN at 2:30pm, on Thursday 9th October, which is 0.09m above tide tables, wind Force 2, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today, Thursday 9th October.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: North Bank of the Humber estuary at Hessle Haven
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed as we are no longer forecasting significant impacts for the tide on Thursday morning. The associated alert remains in place as minor localised impacts are possible relating to the high spring tides. Continue to take care, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the forecast and reissue the warning if required for any tides.

items.description: North Sea coast at Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High tide levels and large waves are expected to lead to flooding this morning, Thursday 09/10/2025. Flooding is possible between 06:00AM and 08:30AM. Areas most at risk include properties on the east side of Kilnsea, and Easington, including the Caravan Parks. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider enacting your flood plan. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 04:00PM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.93 mAODN at 2:00pm, on Thursday 9th October, which is 0.09m above tide tables, wind Force 3, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
High spring tides may lead to flooding this evening. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, however property flooding is not expected.

The highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point, including Porlock Weir, at 8:30 PM on 08/10/2025. Flooding is possible an hour and a half either side of this time.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point of 6.61 mAODN at 8:30 PM on 08/10/2025, with Northerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Further flood alerts may be issued for this current sequence of high Spring tides.

This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Dee Estuary from Parkgate to Chester
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

Highest tide level is expected to be on the Isle of Sheppey and North Kent Coast at 1:45 PM on 09/10/2025. Flooding is possible 1 hour either side of this time.

Areas most at risk include low lying land, promenades and coastal footpaths.

Coastal conditions are expected to improve tomorrow afternoon and no flooding is expected.

We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates.

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Sheerness of 3.46 mAODN at 1:45 PM on 09/10/2025 with westerly force 3 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)

We will remove this message by 2:45 PM on 09/10/2025.
